div.p: The solution of I, (minimum variance) and H , estimation problems is considered using a polynomial systems approach. The results for the lz filtering problem which corresponds with Wiener or Kalman filteringlprediction, are first presented in polynomial matrix form. Attention then turns to the solution of the H , estimation problem for scalar systems. Numerous examples are presented to illustrate the computational procedures. The two types of estimator are appropriate to very different estimation problems and the new H , devices should be valuable in certain application areas.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: HE design of optimal linear filters and predictors is T considered using either an l2 minimum variance estimation error criterion, or a H , minimum estimation error spectrum criterion. The former is a modified Wiener or Kalman filtering problem where colored measurement noise is allowed and a dynamical error weighting function is used. The latter represents a new class of filtering problem motivated by the need to keep the estimation error spectrum small over a range of frequencies. Such a problem may arise in a number of signal processing applications [1]- [3].

For scalar H , estimation problems where the unweighted estimation error is minimized, the optimal error is white noise. Such a device should be valuable in signal detection problems. For control applications it may be necessary to introduce a frequency shaping function so that the optimal error spectral densityfunction will be nonconstant and the error will be nonwhite [ 171. There are important differences between the H , filter and least-squares based filters. The shape of the estimation error spectrum for the filter can be preselected by appropriate choice of weighting function. The choice of error weighting term is therefore crucial in the design of the H , filter. If, for example, a weighting term with constant gain at high and low frequency is employed which has a resonant peak at frequency wo, then the estimation error will be forced to be a minimum at wo. Thus, in applications where it is imperative to force the error to be small in a particular frequency interval, the H , filter is appropriate. Similarly, if the peak of the error spectrum is to be minimized, an H , filter is valuable.
The H , approach used in the solution of the problem described here derives from the work of Kwakernaak [4]- [6] and Grimble [7], [8] on the related H , robust control problems.

The problem considered here might be considered using the "standard problem formulation" of Doyle and solved by the recent state-space approach of Doyle et al. [19]. However, the equations presented by Doyle et al. do not define the optimal solution except in the asymptotic case. This is rather different to the polynomial equations which actually define the optimal solution. It is of course true that these equations cannot normally be solved in an explicit manner but must be solved by iterative methods. Thus, the two approaches are different fundamentally and both have open numerical research questions.

The present work has been brought to fruition in a software package which is now available. It is therefore possible to compute H, filters using this menu driven program. There are of course several other techniques, particularly the state-space approaches which have their own virtues. Thus, although the importance of the new state-space methods must be recognized, the polynomial approach described here is a possible alternative methodology. There are no claims that this is better than the state-space methods, but it is worthy of investigation. If adaptive filters are to be constructed there may be real virtues in the polynomial approach, since the signal model is normally identified in ARMA (polynomial) form.

The I, least-squares multichannel filtering problem is first considered in Sections I1 and 111. The H , filtering problem is then embedded within an l2 problem framework using Lemma 3 which links the two classes of problem. The H , estimation problems are considered in the remaining sections and a full solution is given to the scalar problem with supporting examples. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section VIII.

div.head: IV. THE H , OPTIMAL ESTIMATION PROBLEM
div.p: The least-squares type of estimation problem previously considered is based on Hilbert space concepts and the idea of orthogonal projection. In the frequency domain the integral of the estimation error power spectral density is minimized. However, an alternative requirement might be to minimize the magnitude of the estimation error power spectrum. Thus, rather than minimizing the average error power or error variance which might result in a relatively large error power in certain frequency ranges, the peak error power can be minimized.

By the introduction of frequency weighting functions, in the H , cost-function definition, the error power in selected frequency ranges can be heavily penalized so that the error power is made particularly small in these regions. It follows from the optimality of the estimator that the error power could not be made smaller in these regions, using any other linear filter.

div.head: VIII. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: A polynomial approach to the solution of the f, linear optimal prediction and filtering problems was first presented. The noise model included both white and colored noise components, and a frequency response shaping filter was introduced as a dynamical weighting operator.

A new type of linear estimation problem was then introduced which was related to the minimax control problems considered by Zames [ 141, Kwakernaak [6], Francis Computational algorithms for the solution of the H , estimation problem were described. Examples were also presented to illustrate the computational methods and the procedures. It was seen from these examples that the solution procedure was rather simple and that it does not require high level mathematical tools. It can therefore easily be adopted by control engineers with the numerical support of standard software packages, such as MATLAB or Control-C. It was also clear that H , filters have interesting and different properties to their f2 counterparts. For example, the H, filter with constant weighting enabled the peak of the error spectrum to be reduced considerably. Moreover, by introducing frequency weighting, the error in particular frequency ranges can be reduced to lower values than is possible with an f2 type of filter.

It is an unusual property of the H , filter that the shape of the error spectrum is completely determined a priori by the inverse of the weighting function, whatever the signal and noise model descriptions. The minimum of the error spectrum is determined by the peak of the weighting function and because of the optimality of the filter is the lowest value which can be achieved for any linear filter.
Thus, the H , filter is suitable for applications which require the error spectrum to be made uniformly small, or the error in a particular frequency range to be made as low as possible.

The main benefits of the approach should appear in important applications such as window design [2], ship po-sitioning systems which require low estimation error in certain frequency ranges [ 171, radar detection [ 181, and systems with poorly defined transmission channels [ 2 11.
